fact: Elephants are the largest land animals on Earth.
Giraffes have the longest necks of any animal, which helps them reach leaves high in trees.
Dolphins are highly intelligent and are known for their playful behavior.
Penguins are flightless birds that live mostly in the Southern Hemisphere.
Kangaroos can travel at speeds of up to 35 miles per hour.
Giant pandas spend most of their time eating bamboo.
Sloths are known for their slow movement and spend most of their time hanging upside down in trees.
Tigers are the largest species of the cat family and are known for their powerful build.
Owls have excellent night vision and are skilled hunters.
Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
Koalas sleep for up to 18 hours a day.
Hummingbirds can flap their wings up to 80 times per second.
Polar bears have black skin underneath their white fur to absorb heat from the sun.
Cheetahs are the fastest land animals, capable of running at speeds up to 70 miles per hour.
Platypuses are one of the few mammals that lay eggs.
Whale sharks are the largest fish in the ocean, reaching lengths of up to 40 feet.
Chameleons can change color to blend in with their surroundings.
Armadillos are the only mammals with hard, protective shells.
Kangaroo rats can go their entire lives without drinking water, getting moisture from the seeds they eat.
Bats are the only mammals capable of sustained flight.
Some species of jellyfish are immortal and can revert to their juvenile form after reaching maturity.
Red pandas have a false thumb, an extended wrist bone that helps them grip bamboo.
Narwhals are known for their long, spiral tusks, which are actually elongated teeth.
Sea turtles can live to be over 100 years old.
Lynxes have large, padded paws that act like snowshoes to help them walk on snow.
Meerkats live in large social groups and take turns watching for predators.
Beavers are known for building dams and lodges in rivers and streams.
Gorillas share about 98% of their DNA with humans.
Fennec foxes have large ears that help them dissipate heat and locate prey underground.
Manatees, also known as sea cows, are gentle herbivores that graze on underwater plants.
